p: At the same time, increasing evidence suggests that land cover and land use change affect disease incidence by altering the interactions, abundance, and movement patterns of hosts, vectors, and people [ 13, 14]. For instance, outbreaks of Hantavirus, Lyme disease and tick-borne encephalitis have been associated not only with climate-related changes in the density of host rodent and tick populations [ 15– 17], but also with shifts in the extent and type of land use [ 17– 23].
